name: Use a third party connection pool
description:
This metric will report hibernate.properties or hibernate.cfg.xml files in which the connection pool has been misconfigured or has not been defined at all. 

The connection profile is misconfigured when all of the following requirements are met:

- hibernate.connection.pool_size is defined (means that Hibernate's own connection pool is used)
OR (
   . hibernate.c3p0.max_size is not defined or its value is lower or equal to 1 (means that the c3p0 pool size is not correct)
   AND
   . hibernate.dbcp.maxActive is not defined or its value is lower or equal to 1 (means that the dbcp pool size is not correct)
   AND
   . a property beginning with hibernate.proxool is not defined (means that proxol is not used)
   AND
   . a property hibernate.connection.datasource is not defined (means that no datasource connection pool is used)
   AND
   . a property connection.datasource is not defined (means that no datasource connection pool is used)
   )
   
This list can be completed by a list of other specific third party connection pool properties to check if they are defined.
output:
This report list the XML or .properties file that doesn't define a third party pool.
It provides the following information:
 File Full Name
rationale:
It is very important to define a connection pool to increase database access performances.
Hibernate's own connection pooling algorithm is quite rudimentary. It is intended to help you get started and is not intended for use in a production system or even for performance testing. Use a third party pool for best performance and stability.
remediation:
Use a third party connection pool like:
* c3p0 -  http://sourceforge.net/projects/c3p0 - Distributed with Hibernate
* Apache DBCP -  http://jakarta.apache.org/commons/dbcp/ - Apache Pool
* Proxool - http://proxool.sourceforge.net/   -  JDBC Pooling Wrapper
* a connection pool from an external vendor
remediationSample:
---> hibernate.cfg.xml
...
<hibernate-configuration>
    <!-- a SessionFactory instance listed as /jndi/name -->
    <session-factory
        name="java:comp/env/hibernate/SessionFactory">
        <!-- properties -->
        <property name="connection.datasource">my/first/datasource</property> // FIXED
     ...
    </session-factory>
</hibernate-configuration>

---> or in hibernate.properties
...
hibernate.connection.datasource = my/first/datasource
...
sample:
---> hibernate.cfg.xml
...
<hibernate-configuration>
    <session-factory name="java:comp/env/hibernate/SessionFactory">
       ...
        <property name="connection.pool_size">10</property> // VIOLATION
...

---> or in hibernate.properties
hibernate.connection.pool_size = 10 // VIOLATION
